description: From Middle English joinen, joynen, joignen, from Old French joindre, juindre, jungre, from Latin iungō (“join, yoke”, verb), from Proto-Indo-European *yewg- (“to join, unite”). Cognate with Old English iucian, iugian, ġeocian, ġyċċan (“to join; yoke”). More at yoke.

entries.meaning: An intersection of piping or wiring; an interconnect.
(computing, databases) An intersection of data in two or more database tables.
(computing) The act of joining something, such as a network.
(algebra) The lowest upper bound, an operation between pairs of elements in a lattice, denoted by the symbol ∨.

verbs.description: join (third-person singular simple present joins, present participle joining, simple past and past participle joined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To connect or combine into one; to put together.
examples: The plumber joined the two ends of the broken pipe.
We joined our efforts to get an even better result.
These two rivers join in about 80 miles.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To enter into association or alliance, to unite in a common purpose.
(transitive) To come into the company of.
examples: I will join you watching the football game as soon as I have finished my work.
Many children join a sports club.
Most politicians have joined a party.

entries.meaning: (computing, databases, transitive) To produce an intersection of data in two or more database tables.
examples: By joining the Customer table on the Product table, we can show each customer's name alongside the products they have ordered.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) To enjoin upon; to command.
examples: They join them penance, as they call it.

entries.meaning: To accept, or engage in, as a contest.
examples: to join encounter, battle, or issue
